titleStmt.title: Chapman, George, 1559?-1634: Sir Gyles Goosecappe: Knight (1606)

publicationStmt.publisher: George Chapman, 1559?-1634 (1559?-1634) Sir Gyles Goosecappe: Knight. A Comedie presented by the Chil. of the Chappell London Printed by Iohn Windet for Edward Blunt 1606

sourceDesc.p:
Play details
Sir Gyles Goosecappe: knight. Genre: Comedy. Date first published: 1606. Date first performed: 18 Sep 1602.

encodingDesc.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Iack. Will. Bullaker Rudesby Gyles Goosecappe. Fowlewether Eugenia Wynnifred Hyppolita Penelope Clarence Momford Tales Kingcob Furnsfall Doctor Messenger Horatio more than one speaker unnamed servant

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by IDREF which point to the following.

sp.speaker: Bullaker
sp.l: This is the Countess Eugenias house I think, I can never hit of these same English City houses, though I were borne here: if I were in any City in Fraunce, I could find any house there at midnight.

sp.speaker: Iack.
sp.l: These two strange hungry knights ( Will ) make the leanest trenchers that ever I waited on.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.l: A plague on them Jack, they leave us no fees at all, for our attendance, I think they use to set their bones in silver they pick them so clean, see, see, see Jack, what is that?

sp.speaker: Iack
sp.l: A my word Will) it is the great Baboon, that was to be seen in Southwarke.

sp.speaker: VVill
sp.l: Is this he? gods my life what beasts were we, that we would not see him all this while, never trust me if he look not somewhat like a man, see how prettily he holds the torch in one of his forefeet, where is his keeper trow, is he broke loose?

sp.speaker: Iack
sp.l: Hast ever an Apple about thee ( Will ) we will take him up sure, we shall get a monstrous deal of money with him.

sp.speaker: VVil.
sp.l: That we shall i'faith boy, and look thou here, here is a red cheeked apple to take him up with.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Excellent fit a my credit, let us lay down our provant, and to him.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.l: I will let them alone a while.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Give me the apple to take up because my name is Iacke.

sp.speaker: VVil
sp.l: Hold thee Iacke, take it.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Come Iacke, come Iacke, come Iacke.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.l: I will come to your Sir, I will Iacke ye at my word, I will Iacke ye.

sp.speaker: VVill
sp.l: Gods me he speaks Iacke, O pray pardon us Sir.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.l: Out ye moped monkeys can yenot know a man from a Marmoset, in these Frenchified days of ours? nay I will Iackefie you a little better yet.

sp.speaker: both,
sp.l: Nay good Sir, good Sir, pardon us.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.l: Pardon us, out ye home-bred peasants, plain english, pardon us, if you had parleyed, and not spoken, but said pardon moy; I would have pardoned you, but since you speak, and not parley, I will cudgel ye better yet.

sp.speaker: Ambo
sp.l: O pardon moy monsieur.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.l: Bien ie vous remercie, thers pardonne pour vous Sir now.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.l: Why I thank ye for it Sir, you seem to be a Squire of our order Sir.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Whose page might you be Sir.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.l: I am now the great French Travellers page.

sp.speaker: Wil
sp.l: Or rather the french Travellers great page. Sir, on, on

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.l: Hight Captain foul-weather, alias Commendations; whose valours within here at super with the Countess Eugenia, whose proper eaters I take you two to be.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.l: You mistake us not Sir.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: This captain foul-weather, alias Commendations (Will) is the gallant that will needs be a suitor to our Countess

sp.speaker: Will
sp.l: Faith and if foul-weather be a welcome suitor to a fair Lady, has good luck.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: O Sir, beware of one that can shower into the laps of Ladies, Captain foul-weather? why he is a Captinado, or Captain of Captains, and will lie in their joints that give him cause to work upon them so heavily, that he will make their hearts ache I warrant him; Captain foul-weather? why he will make the cold stones sweat for fear of him, a day or two before he come at them. Captain foul-weather? why he does so domineer, and reign over women.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.l: A plague of Captain foul-weather. I remember him now Jack, and know him to be a dull moist brained Ass.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: A Southern man I think.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.l: As fearful as a Hare, and he; will lie like a Lapwing, and; I know how he came to be a Captain, and; to have his Surname of Commendations.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: How I prithee Will?

sp.speaker: Will
sp.l: Why Sir he served the great Lady Kingcob, and was yeoman of her wardrobe, and because he could brush up her silks lustily, she thought he would curry the enemies coats as soundly, and so by her commendations, he was made Captain in the low Countries.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Then being made Captain only by his Ladies commendations, without any worth also of his own, he was ever after surnamed Captain Commendations?

sp.speaker: Will
sp.l: Right.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.l: Aye Sir right, but if he had not said right, my Captain should have taken no wrong at his hands, nor yours neither I can tell ye.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: What are those two Knights names, that are thy captains Comrades, and within at supper with our Lady?

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.l: One of their names Sir, is, Sir Gyles Goose-cap, the others Sir Cutt. Rudseby.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.l: Sir Gyles Goose-cap what is he a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.l: Aye that he is at least if he be not a noble man, and his chief house is in Essex.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: In Essex? did not his Ancestors come out of London

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.l: Yes that they did Sir, the best Goose-caps in England, comes out of London I assure you.

sp.speaker: VVill
sp.l: Aye but Sir these must come into it before they come out of it I hope, but what countryman is Sir Cutt. Rudeby?

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.l: A Northern man, or a Westernman I take him, but my Captain is the Emphatical man; and by that pretty word Emphatical you shall partly know him; for it is a very forcible word in troth, and yet he forces it too much by his favour; marry no more than he does all the rest of his words; with whose multiplicity often times he travails himself out of all good company.

sp.speaker: Iack
sp.l: Like enough; he travailed for nothing else.

sp.speaker: VVil
sp.l: But what qualities haunt Sir Gyles Goosecap now Sir?

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.l: Sir Gyles Goosecap has always a deaths head (as it were) in his mouth, for his only one reason for everything is, because we are all mortal; and therefore he is generally called the mortal knight; then hath he another pretty phrase too, and that is, he will tickle the vanity on it still in everything and this is your Summa totalis of both their virtues.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: It is enough, it is enough, as long as they have land enough, but now muster your third person afore us I beseech you,

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.l: The third person and second knight blunt Sir Cutt. Rudesby, is indeed blunt at a sharpe wit, and sharpe at a blunt wit a good bustling gallant talks well at Rovers; he is two parts soldier; as slovenly as a Switzer, and somewhat like one in face too; for he wears a bush beard will dead a Cannon short better than a wool-pack: he will come into the presence like your Frenchman in foul boots: and dares eat garlic as a preparative to his Courtship; you shall know more of him hereafter; but good wags let me win you now, for the Geographical parts of your Ladies in requital.

sp.speaker: Wil
sp.l: That you shall Sir, and the Hydrographicall too and you will; first my Lady the widow, and Countess Eugenia, is in earnest, a most worthy Lady, and indeed can do more than a thousand other Ladies can do I can tell ye.

sp.speaker: Bvl
sp.l: What is that I pray thee?

sp.speaker: Iack.
sp.l: Marry Sir, he means she can do more than sleep, and eat and drink; and play at noddy, and help to make herself ready.

sp.speaker: Bul
sp.l: Can she so?

sp.speaker: Will
sp.l: She is the best scholar of any woman but one in England, she is wise and virtuous,

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Nay she has one strange quality for a woman besides, though these be strange enough that he has reckoned.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.l: For Gods sake what is that?

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: She can love reasonable constantly, for she loved her husband only, almost a whole year together.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.l: That is strange indeed, but what is your fair Lady Sir?

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: My Lady Sir, the Lady Hippolita.

sp.speaker: VVill
sp.l: That is as chaste as ever was Hippolitus.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: (True my pretty Parenthesis) is half a maid, half a wife, and half a widow.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.l: Strange tale to tell; how canst thou make this good my good Assumpsit.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Thus Sir, she was betrothed to a gallant young gentleman that loved her with such passion and admiration that he never thought he could be so blessed as to enjoy her in full marriage, till the minister was marrying them, and even then when he was saying I Charles take thee Hippolita; with extreme joy he began to look pale, then going forwards saying to my wedded wife, he looked paler, and, then pronouncing, for richer for poorer as long as we both shall live , he looked extreme pale; Now sir when she comes to speak her part, and said, I Hippolota take thee Charles, he began to faint for joy, then saying to my wedded husband, he began to sink, but then going forth to for better for worse, he could stand no longer but with very conceit it seemed, that she whom he tendered as the best of all things, should pronounce the worst, and for his sake too, he sunk down right, and died suddenly: And thus being half married, and her half husband wholly dead, I hope I may with discretion affirm her, half a maid, half a wife, and half a widow; do ye conceive me Sir?

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.l: O Lord Sir, I devour you quick; and now Sir I beseech you open unto me your the other Lady, what is she ?

sp.speaker: Will
sp.l: I will answer for her, because I know her Ladyship to be a perfect maid indeed.

sp.speaker: Bul
sp.l: How canst thou know that?

sp.speaker: Will
sp.l: Passing perfectly I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: By measuring her neck twice, and trying if it will come about her forehead, and slip over her nose?

sp.speaker: VVill
sp.l: No Sir no, by a rule that will not slip so I warrant you, which for her honours sake I will let slip unto you, gods so Jack, I think they have supped.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: ByrLady we have waited well the while.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.l: Well though they have lost their attendance, let not us lose our Suppers Jack.

sp.speaker: Iack
sp.l: I do not mean it, come Sir you shall go in and drink with us i'faith.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.l: Pardon moy monsieur.

sp.speaker: both
sp.l: No pardoning in truth Sir.

body.stage: Enter Goosecappe Rudesby Fouleweather> Eugenia Hippol. Penelope, Wynne.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: A plague on you sweet Ladies, it is not so late, what needed you to have made so short a supper.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.l: In truth Sir Cutt. we might have tickled the vanity on it , an hour longer if my watch be trustable.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: Aye but how should these beauties know that Sir Gyles? your watch is mortal, and may err.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: That is sooth Captain, but do you hear honest friend pray take a light, and see if the moon shine, I have a Sun dial will resolve presently.

sp.speaker: Fo.
sp.l: Howsoever believe it Ladies, it is unwholesome, uncourtly, unpleasant to eat hastily, and rise suddenly, a man can show no discourse, no wit, no stirring, no variety, no pretty conceits, to make the meat go down emphatically,

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Winnefred.

sp.speaker: Winnefred.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: I prithee go to my uncle the Lord Momford, and entreat him to come quicken our ears with some of his pleasant Spirit; This same foul-weather has made me so melancholy, prithee make haste.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: I will madam.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: We will bid our guests good night madam, this same foul-weather makes me so sleepy.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Fie upon it, for Gods sake shut the Casements, here is such a fulsome air comes into this chamber; in good faith madam you must keep your house in better reparations, this same foul-weather beats in so filthily.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I will take order with the Porter for it Lady, good night gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Why good night and be hanged, and you will needs be gone.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.l: God give you good night madams, thank you for my good cheer, we will tickle the vanity on it, no longer with you at this time, but I will indict your La: to supper at my lodging one of these mornings; and that ere long too, because we are all mortal you know.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Light the Lady Penelope, and the Lady Hippolita to their chambers, good night fair Ladies.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Good night madam, I wish you may sleep well after your light supper.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I warrant you Lady I shall never be troubled with dreaming of my French Suitor.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Why how now my Frenchified captain foul-weather? by gods lid thy Surname is never thought upon here, I perceive here is nobody gives thee any commendations.

sp.speaker: Fo.
sp.l: Why this is the untravailed rudeness of our gross English Ladies now would any French Lady use a man thus think ye? be they any way so uncivil, and fulsome? they say they wear foul smocks, and course smocks, I say they lie, and I will die in it .

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: Aye, do so, pray thee, thou shalt die in a very honourable cause, thy countries general quarrel right.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: Their smocks quoth you? a my word you shall take them up so white, and so pure, so sweet, so Emphatical, so moving.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: Aye marry Sir, I think they be continually moving.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: But if their smocks were Course or foul.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: Nay I warrant thee thou carest not, so thou wert at them.

sp.speaker: Foul
sp.l: 'sdeath they put not all their virtues in their smocks, or in their mocks, or in their stewed cocks as our Ladies do .

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: But in their stewed pox, there is all their gentility.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.l: Nay good Sir Cutt. do not aggravate him no more.

sp.speaker: Fowl.
sp.l: Then are they so kind, so wise, so familiar so noble, so sweet in entertainment, that when you shall, have cause to discourse or sometimes to come nearer them; if your breath be ill, your teeth ill, or anything about you ill, why they will presently break with ye, in kind sort, good terms, pretty experiments, and tell you plain this; thus it is with your breath Sir, thus it is with your teeth Sir, this is your disease, and this is your medicine.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.l: As I am true mortal Knight, it is most superlatively good, this.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: Why this is Courtly now, this is sweet, this plain, this is familiar, but by the Court of France, our peevish dames are so proud, so precise, so coy, so disdainful, and so subtle, as the Pomonean Serpent, mort dieu the Punk of Babylon was never so subtle.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: Nay do not chafe so Captain.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: Your Frenchman would ever chafe Sir Cutt. being thus moved.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: What? and play with his beard so.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: Aye and bristle, it doth express that passion of anger very full and emphatical.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.l: Nay good knight if your French would bristle, let him alone, in troth our Ladies are a little too coy and subtle Captain indeed.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: Subtle Sir Giles Goose-cap? I assure your Soul, they are as subtle with their suitors, or loves, as the Latin Dialect where the nominative Case, and the verb, the Substantive, and the Adjective, the verb, and the verb, stand as far asunder , as if they were perfect strangers one to another; and you shall hardly find them out, but then learn to Construe, and parse them, and you shall find them prepared, and acquainted, and agree together, in Case, gender, and number.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.l: I detest Sir Cutt, I did not think he had been half the quintessence of a scholar he is.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: 'slid there is not one of them truly emphatical.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.l: Yes I will ensure you Captain, there are many of them truly Emphatical but all your French Ladies are not fat? are they Sir?

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: Fat Sir, why do ye think Emphatical is fat Sir Giles?

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: God is my life brother knight, didst thou think so? heart I know not what it is myself, but yet I never thought it was fat, I will be sworn to thee.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: Why if any true Courtly dame had had but this new fashioned suit, to entertain anything in differently stuffed, why you should have had her more respective by far .

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: Nay there is some reason for that Captain, methinks a true woman should perpetually dote upon a new fashion.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: Why you are in the right Sir Cutt. Jn noua fert Animus mutatas dicere formas. it is the mind of man, and woman to affect new fashions; but to our Mynsatiues forsooth, if he come like to your Besognio, or your bore, so he be rich, or emphatical, they care not; would I might never excel a dutch Skipper in Courtship if I did not put distaste into my carriage of purpose; I knew I should not please them. Lackey? allume le torch.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: 'slid, here is neither Torch, nor Lackey methinks ,

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: O mon dieu.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: O do not swear Captain.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: Your Frenchman ever swears Sir Cutt, upon the lack of his Lackey I assure you.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.l: See here he comes, and my Ladies two pages, they have been tickling the vanity of it i'faith.

body.stage: Enter to them Iack, Bullaker, Will.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Captain foul-weather, my Lady the Countess Eugenia commends her most kindly to you, and is determined tomorrow morning early if it be a frost to take her Coach to Barnet to be nipped where if it please you, to meet her, and accompany her homeward, joining your wit with the frost, and help to nip her. She does not doubt but though you had a sad supper, you will have a joyful breakfast.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: I shall indeed my dear youth.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: Why Captain I abused thee, I see: I said the Ladies respected thee not, and now I perceive the widow is in love with thee.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: 'sblood knight I knew I had struck her to the quick, I wondered she departed in that extravagant fashion: I am sure I past one Passado of Courtship upon her, that has heretofore made a lane amongst the French Ladies like a Culvering shot, I will be sworn; and I think Sir Gyles you saw how she fell under it.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.l: O as clear as candlelight, by this daylight.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: O good knight at the post, he will swear anything.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.l: The other two Ladies commend them no less kindly to you two knights too; and desire your worships would meet them at Barnet in the morning with the Captain.

sp.speaker: Foul. Goos. Rud.
sp.l: O good Sir.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.l: Our worships shall attend their Ladyships thither.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: No Sir Giles by no means, they will go privately thither, but if you will meet them there.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: Meet them, we will die for it , but we will meet them.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: Let us go thither tonight knights, and you be true gallants.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: Content.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: How greedily they take it in Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.l: No it is too far to go tonight, we will be up betimes in the morning, and not go to bed at all.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: Why it is but ten miles, and a fine clear night Sir Gyles

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.l: But ten miles? what do ye talk Captain?

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: Why dost think it is any more?

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.l: I, I will lay ten pounds it is more than ten mile, or twelve either.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: What to Barnet

sp.speaker: Gous.
sp.l: Aye , to Barnet

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: 'slid, I will lay a hundred pound with thee, if thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.l: I will lay five hundred, to a hundred, Slight I will not be outborne with a wager, in that I know, I am sure it was four years ago ten miles thither, and I hope it is more now, 'slid do not miles grow think you, as well as other Animals.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: O wise Knight!

sp.speaker: Gos.
sp.l: I never Inned in the Town but once, and then they lodged me in a Chamber so full of these Ridiculous Fleas, that I was fain to lie standing all night, and yet I made my man rise, and put out the candle too, because they should not see to bite me.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: A pretty project.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.l: In truth Captain if I might advise you, you should tarry, and take the morning afore you.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: How? O mon Dieu, how the villain poltroon, dishonours his travail? you Buffoonly Mouchroun, are you so mere rude, and English to advise your Captain?

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Nay I prithee foul-weather be not tempestuous with thy poor Lackey.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: tempestuous Sir Cutt, will your Frenchman think you, suffer his Lackey to advise him?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: O God you must take heed Lackey how you advise your captain, your French lackey would not have done it.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: He would have been poxed first: Allume le torch, sweet pages commend us to your Ladies, say we kiss their white hands, and will not fail to meet them: knights which of you leads?

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.l: Not we Sir, you are a Captain, and a leader.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: Besides, thou art commended for the better man, for thou art very Commendations itself, and Captain Commendations.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: Why, what though I be Captain Commendations?

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: Why and Captain commendations, is hearty? commendations, for Captains are hearty I am sure, or else hang them,

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: Why, what if I be hearty Commendations, come, come, sweet knights lead the way.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: O Lord Sir, always after my hearty Commendations.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: Nay then you conquer me with president, by the Authentical form of all Justice letters. Alloun.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Here is a most sweet Gudgeon swallowed, is there not?

sp.speaker: Will
sp.l: Aye but how will they digest it thinkest thou? when they shall find our Ladies not there?

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: I have a vaunt currying devise shall make them digest it most healthfully.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Work on sweet love, I am not yet resolved
To exhaust this troubled spring of vanities
And nurse of perturbations, my poor life,
And therefore since in every man that holds
This being dear, there must be some desire
Whose power to enjoy his object may so mask
The Judging part that in her radiant eyes
His estimation of the world may seem
Upright, and worthy, I have chosen love
To blind my Reason with his misty hands
And make my estimative power believe
I have a project worthy to employ
What worth so ever my whole man affords:
Then sit at rest my Soul, thou now hast found
The end of thy infusion, in the eyes
Of thy divine Eugenia look for heaven.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Thanks gentle friends is your good Lord and mine, gone up to bed yet?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: I do assure ye not Sir, not yet, nor yet, my deep, and studious friend, not yet musical Clarence.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: My Lord?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Nor yet, thou sole divider of my Lordship.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: That were a most unfit division
And far above the pitch of my low plumes
I am your bold and constant guest my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Far, far from bold, for thou hast known me long
Almost these twenty years, and half those years
Hast been my bedfellow; long time before
This unseen thing, this thing of naught indeed
Or Atom called, my Lordship shined in me,
And yet thou makest thyself as little bold
To take such kindness, as becomes the Age
And truth of our indissoluble love
As our acquaintance sprung but yesterday
Such is thy gentle and too tender Spirit.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: My Lord, my want of Courtship makes me fear
I should be rude, and this my mean estate
Meets with such envy, and detraction
Such misconstructions, and resolved misdooms
Of my poor worth, that should I be advanced
Beyond my unseen lowness, but one hair
I should be torn in pieces with the Spirits
That fly in ill lunged tempests through the world,
Tearing the head of virtue from her shoulders
If she but look out of the ground of glory.
Twixt, whom, and me and every worldly fortune
There fights such sour, and Cursed Antipathy
So waspish, and so petulant a Star,
That all things tending to my grace or good
Are ravished from their object, as I were
A thing created for a wilderness
And must not think of any place with men.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: O hark you Sir, this wayward mood of yours must sifted be, or rather rooted out, you will no more music Sir?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Not now my Lord,

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Be gone my masters then to bed, to bed.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I thank you honest friends

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Hence with this book, and now Monsieur Clarence, me thinks plain and prose friendship would do excellent well betwixt us come thus Sir, or rather thus, come Sir it is time I trow that we both lived like one body, thus, and that both our sides were slit, and Concorporate with Organs fit to effect an individual passage even for our very thoughts; suppose we were one body now, and I charge you believe it; whereof I am the heart, and you the liver.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Your Lordship might well make that division if you knew the plain song.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: O Sir, and why so I pray?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: First because the heart, is the more worthy entrail, being the first that is borne, and moves, and the last that moves, and dies; and then being the fountain of heat too, for wheresoever our heat does not flow directly from the heart to the other Organs, there, their action must of necessity cease, and so without you I neither would nor could live .

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Well Sir for these reasons I may be the heart why may you be the liver now?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I am more than ashamed, to tell you that my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Nay nay be not too suspicious of my judgment, in you I beseech you: ashamed friend? if your love overcome not that shame, a shame take that love I say. Come sir why may you be the liver?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: The plain and short truth is (my Lord) because I am all liver, and turned lover.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Lover?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Lover i'faith my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Now I prithee let me leap out of my skin for joy why thou wilt not now revive the sociable mirth of thy sweet disposition? wilt thou shine in the world anew ? and make those that have slighted thy love, with the Austerity of thy knowledge, dote on thee again with thy commanding shaft of their humours?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Alas my Lord they are all far out of my aim; and only to fit myself a little better to your friendship, have I given these wilful reins to my affections.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: And i'faith is my sower friend to all worldly desires overtaken with the heart of the world? Love I shall be monstrous proud now, to hear she is every way a most rare woman that I know thy spirit, and judgment hath chosen, is she wise? is she noble? is she capable of thy virtues? will she kiss this forehead with judicial lips? where so much judgment and virtue deserves it? Come brother Twin, be short I charge you, and name me the woman.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Since your Lordship will shorten the length of my follies relation, the woman that I so passionately love, is no worse Lady than your own Niece, the too worthy Countess Eugenia.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Why so, so, so, you are a worthy friend are you not to conceal this love-mine in your head, and would not open it to your heart, now beshrew my heart, if my heart dance not for joy though my heels do not, and they do not, because I will not set that at my heels that my friends set at his heart, what? friend and Nephew? both nephew is a far inferior title to friend I confess, but I will prefer the backwards (as many friends do) and leave their friends worse than they found them,

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: But my noble Lo. it is almost a prodigy, that I being only a poor Gentleman and far short of that state and wealth that a Lady of her greatness in both will expect in her husband.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Hold thy doubt friend, never fear any woman, unless thyself be made of straw, or some such dry matter, and she of lightning, Audacity prospers above probability in all worldly matters, dost not thou know that Fortune governs them without order, and therefore reason the mother of order is none of her counsel, why should a man desiring to aspire an unreasonable creature which is a woman? seek her fruition by reasonable means, because thyself binds upon reason, wilt thou look for congruity in a woman? why? there is not one woman amongst one thousand, but will speak false Latin, and break Priscians head, attempt nothing that you may with great reason doubt of, and out of doubt you shall obtain nothing, I tell thee friend the eminent confidence of strong spirits is the only witchcraft of this world, Spirits wrestling with spirits, as bodies? with bodies? this were enough to make the hope well, if she were one of these painted communities, that are ravished with Coaches, and upper hands, and brave men of dirt: but thou knowest friend she is a good scholar, and like enough to bite at the rightest reason, and reason evermore Ad optima hortetur: to like that which is best, not that which is bravest, or rightest, or greatest, and so consequently worst, But prove what she can, we will turn her, and wind her, and make her so pliant that we will draw her through a wedding ring i'faith.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Would to god we might my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: I will warrant thee friend,

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Where is mistress Winnyfred; for my Lady Eugenia desires to speak with your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Marry enter mistress Winnifred even here I pray thee, from the Lady Eugenia do you hear friend?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Very easily on that side my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Let me feel? does not thy heart pant apace, by my heart well laboured Cupid, the field is yours sir God, and upon a very honourable composition, I am sent for now I am sure, and must even truss, and to her:
witty mistress Winnifred, nay come near woman I am sure this Gentleman thinks his chamber the sweeter for your dear presence.

sp.speaker: Win,
sp.l: My absence shall thank him my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: What rude Mistress Winnifred? nay faith you shall come to him, and kiss him, for his kindness.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Nay good my Lord, I will never go to the market for that ware I can have it brought home to my door

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: O Winnifred, a man may know by the market folks how the market goes.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: So you may my Lord, but I know few Lords that think scorn to go to that market themselves.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: To go to it Winnifred, it nay to ride to; it i'faith.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: That is more than I know my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: You will not believe it till you are then a horseback, will ye?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Come, come, I am sent of a message to you will you hear it?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Stop, stop fair Winnifred, would you have audience so soon, there were no state in that i'faith; this fair gentlewoman sir.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Now we shall have a fiction I believe.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Had three Suitors at once.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: You will leave out none my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mom,
sp.l: No more did you Winnifred you interfered with them all in truth.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: O Monstrous Lord by this light!

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Now Sir to make my tale short I will do that which she did not; viz. leave out the two first, the third coming the third night for his turn.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: My Lord, my Lord, my Lady does that, that nobody else does, desires your company and so fare you well.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: O stay a little sweet Winnifred, help me but to truss my points again, and have with you.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Not I by my truth my Lord, I had rather see your hose about your heels, then I would help you to truss a point.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: O witty Winnifred? for that Jest, take thy passport, and tell thy Ladies thou leftest me with my hose about my heels.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Well, well my Lord you shall sit till the moss grow about your heels, ere I come at you again.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: She cannot abide to hear of her three Suitors; but is not this very fit my sweet Clarence? Thou seest my rare Niece cannot sleep without me; but for thy company sake, she shall tonight; and in the morning I will visit her early; when do thou but stand in that place, and thou mayst chance hear, (but art sure to see) in what subtle, and farfetched manner I will solicit her about thee.

sp.speaker: Cla
sp.l: Thanks worthy Lord.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I That have studied with world scorning thoughts
the way of heaven, and how true heaven is reached
To know how mighty, and how many are
The strange affections of enchanted number
How to distinguish all the motions
Of the Celestial bodies, and what power
doth separate in such form this massy Round:
What is his Essence, Efficacies, Beams?
Footsteps, and Shadows? what Eternesses is
The world, and Time, and Generation?
What Soul, the worlds Soul is? what the black Springs
And unrevealed Original of Things,
What their perseverance; what is life and death,
And what our Certain Restoration?
Am with the staid-heads of this Time employed
To watch withal my Nerves a Female shade.

body.stage: Enter Wynnefred, Anabell, with their sowing workes and sing: After their song Enter Lord Momford.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Witty Mistress Wynnefred, where is your Countess I pray?

sp.speaker: Wyn.
sp.l: Faith your Lordship is bold enough to seek her out, if she were at her urinal?

sp.speaker: Mom.
Eu.
sp.l: What, can you not abide my maids uncle?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: I never could abide a maid in my life Niece, but either I draw away the maid, or the maidenhead with a wet finger.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: You love to make your your self worse than you are still.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: I know few mend in this world Madam, For the worse the better thought on, the better the worse spoken on ever amongst women.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: I wonder where you have been all this while with your sentences.

sp.speaker: Mom,
sp.l: Faith where I must be again presently. I cannot stay long with you my dear Niece.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: By my faith but you shall my Lord, Gods pity what will become of you shortly, that you drive maids afore you, and offer to leave widows behind you, as mankindly, as if you had taken a surfeit of our Sex lately, and our very sight turned your stomach.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: God is my life, She abuses her best uncle; never trust me if it were not a good revenge to help her to the loss of her widowhead.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: That were a revenge and a half, indeed.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Nay it were but a whole revenge Niece, but such a revenge as would more than observe the true rule of a revenge.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: I know your rule before you utter it, Vlciscere Inimico sed sine tuo incommodo.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: O rare Niece, you may see, what it is to be a scholar now, Learning in a woman is like weight in gold, or Luster in Diamonds, which in no other Stone is so rich or refulgent

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: But say dear Uncle how could you find in your heart to stay so long from me.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Why alas Niece, you are so smeared with this willful widows three years black weed, that I never come to you, but I dream of Courses, and Sepulchres, and Epitaphs, all the night after, and therefore adieu dear Niece.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Beshrew my heart my Lord, if you go these three hours.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Three hours? nay Niece, if I dance attendance three hours (alone in her chamber) with an Lady so near allied to me, I am very idle in faith, marry with such an other; I would dance, one, two, three, four, and five, though it cost me ten shillings; and now I am in, have at it, my head must devise something while my feet are piddling thus, that may bring her to some fit consideration of my friend, who indeed is only a great scholar, and all his honours, and riches lie in his mind.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Come, Come, pray tell me uncle, how does my cousin Momford?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Why, well, very well Niece, and so is my friend Clarence well too, and then is there a worthy gentleman well as any is in England I can tell ye.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: But when did you see my Cousin?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: And it is pity but he should do well, and he shall be well too, if all my wealth will make him well.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: What means he by this trow ye, your Lo: is very dancitive methinks.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Aye , and I could tell you a thing would make your Ladyship very dancitive, or else it were very dunsatiue i'faith. O how the skipping of this Christmas block of ours moves the blockhead heart of a woman, and indeed anything that pleaseth the foolish eye which presently runs with a lying tale of Excellence to the mind.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: But I pray tell me my Lord could you tell me of a thing would make me dance say you?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Well, farewell sweet Niece I must needs take my leave in earnest.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Lord bless us, here is such a stir with your farewells.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: I will see you again within these two or three days on my word Niece.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Gods precious, two or three days? why this Lord is in a marvelous strange humour. Sit down sweet Uncle, i'faith I have to talk with you about great matters.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Say then dear Niece, be short utter your mind quickly now.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: But I pray tell me first, what is that would make me dance i'faith?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Dance, what dance? hitherto your dancers legs bow forsooth, and Caper, and Jerk, and Firk, and dandle the body above them, as it were their great child, though the special Jerker be above this place I hope, here lies that should fetch a perfect woman over the Coals i'faith.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Nay good Uncle say what is the thing you could tell me of.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: No matter, no matter: But let me see a passing prosperous forehead of an exceeding happy distance betwixt the eye brows; a clear lightning eye; a temperate and fresh blood in both the cheeks; excellent marks, most excellent marks of good fortune.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Why, how now Uncle did you never see me before?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Yes Niece; but the state of these things at this instant must be specially observed, and these outward signs being now in this clear elevation, show your untroubled mind is in an excellent power, to prefer them to act forth then a little dear Niece.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: This is excellent.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: The Creases here are excellent good; The proportion of the chin good; the little aptness of it to stick out; good. And the wart above it most exceeding good. Never trust me, if all things be not answerable to the prediction of a most divine fortune towards her; now if she have the grace to apprehend it in the nick; there is all.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Well my Lord, since you will not tell me your secret, I will keep another from you; with whose discovery, you may much pleasure me, and whose concealment may hurt my estate. And if you be no kinder than to see me so endangered; I will be very patient of it I assure you.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Nay then it must instantly forth. This kind conjuration even fires it out of me; and (to be short) gather all your Judgment together, for here it comes. Niece; Clarence Clarence, rather my Soul than my fried Clarence of too substantial a worth, to have any figures cast about him, (notwithstanding, no other woman with Empires could stir his affections) is with your virtues most extremely in love; and without your requital dead. And with it Fame shall sound this golden distich through the world of you both.

l.foreign: Non illo melior quisquam nec amantior qui
Vir fuit, aut illa reuerentior vlla Dearum.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Aye me poor Dame, O you amaze me Uncle,
Is this the wondrous fortune you presage?
What man may miserable women trust?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: O peace good Lady, I come not to ravish you to anything. But now I see how you accept my motion: I perceive (how upon true trial) you esteem me. Have I rid all this Circuit to levy the powers of your Judgment, that I might not prove their strength too suddenly with so violent a charge: And do they fight it out in white blood. And show me their hearts in the soft Crystal of tears

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: O uncle you have wounded your yourself in charging me that I should shun Judgment as a monster, if it would not weep; I place the poor felicity of this world in a worthy friend, and to see him so unworthily revolted, I shed not the tears of my Brain, but the tears of my soul. And if ever nature made tears the effects of any worthy cause, I am sure I now shed them worthily.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Her sensual powers are up i'faith, I have thrust her soul quite from her Tribunal. This is her Sedes vacans when her subjects are privileged to libel against her, and her friends. But weeps my kind Niece for the wounds of my friendship? and I touched in friendship for wishing my friend doubled in her singular happiness?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: How am I doubled? when my honour, and good name, two essential parts of me;would be less, and lost?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: In whose Judgment?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: In the judgment of the world.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Which is a fools bolt. Nihil a virtute nec a viritate remotius quam Vulgaris opinion : But my dear Niece, it is most true that your honour and good name tendered as they are the species of truth are worthily two essential parts of you; But as they consist only in airy titles and corruptible blood (whose bitterness sanitas et non nobilitas efficit ) and care not how many base and execrable acts they commit, they touch you no more than they touch eternity. And yet shall no nobility you have in either, be impaired neither.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Not to marry a poor gentleman?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Respect him not so; for as he is a gentleman he is noble; as he is wealthily furnished with true knowledge, he is rich and therein adorned with the exactest complements belonging to everlasting nobleness.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Which yet will not maintain him a week: Such kind of nobleness gives no cotes of honour nor can scarce get a cote for necessity

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Then is it not substantial knowledge (as it is in him) but verbal and fantastical for Omnia in illa ille complexu tenet.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Why seeks he me then?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: To make you joint partners with him in all things, and there is but a little partial difference betwixt you, that hinders that universal jointure: The bigness of this circle held too near our eye keeps it from the whole Sphere of: the Sun but; could we sustain it indifferently betwixt us and it, it would then without check of one beam appear in his fulness.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Good Uncle be content for now shall I never dream of contentment.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: I have more than done Lady, and had rather have suffered an alteration of my being than of your Judgment; but (dear niece) for your own honour sake repair it instantly.
See here comes the Ladies; make an April day one dear love and be suddenly cheerful God save you more than fair Ladies, I am glad you are come, for my business will have me gone presently.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Why my Lord Momford I say? will you go before dinner?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: No remedy sweet Beauties, for which rudeness I lay my hands thus low for your pardons:

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: O Courteous Lord Momford!

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Niece? Meus estqu sola quietos.

l.foreign: Sola facit claros ment emque honoribus ornat
Uerus honos Iuuat at mendax infamia terret.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Mine own dear nephew?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What success my Lord?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Excellent; excellent; come I will tell thee all.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Do you hear madam, how our youths here have gulled our three suitors?

sp.speaker: Eug
sp.l: Not I Lady, I hope our suitors are no fit meat for our Pages.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: No madam, but they are fit sauce for any man's meat I will warrant them.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: What is the matter Hippolita?

sp.speaker: Hp.
sp.l: They have sent the knights to Barnet madam this frosty morning to meet us there .

sp.speaker: Eug
sp.l: Is it true youths, are knights fit subjects for your knaveries?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Pray pardon us madam, we would be glad to please anybody.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Aye indeed madam and we were sure we pleased them highly to tell them you were desirous of their company.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: O it was good Eugenia, their livers were too hot, you know, and for temper sake they must needs have a cooling card played upon them.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: And besides madam we would have them know that your two little Pages, which are less by half than two leaves, have more learning in them than is in all their three volumes.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: in faith Will; and putt their great pagicall index to them too.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: But how will ye excuse your abuses wags?

sp.speaker: Will
sp.l: We doubt not madam, but if it please your Ladyship to put up their abuses,

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Trusting they are not so dear to you, but you may.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.l: We shall make them gladly furnish their pockets with them.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Well, children, and fowls, agree as you will, and let the world know now, women have nothing to do with you.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: Come madam I think your dinner be almost ready,

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: And see, here are two honourable guests for you, the Lord Tales, and Sir Cutberd Kingcob.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: Lack you any guests madam?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Aye my Lord such guests as you.

sp.speaker: Hip
sp.l: There is as common an answer, as yours was a question my Lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why? all things should be common betwixt Lords, and Ladies you know.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Indeed Sir Kuttberd Bingcob, I have heard, you are either of the family of Love, or of no religion at all.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: He may well be said to be of the family of Love, he does so flow in the loves of poor overthrown Ladies.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You speak of that I would do madam, but in earnest, I am now suing for a new mistress; look in my hand sweet Lady, and tell me what fortune I shall have with her.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Do you think me a witch, Sir Cutberd?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Pardon me Madam, but I know you to be learned in all things.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Come on let us see.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: He does you a special favour Lady, to give you his open hand, for it is commonly shut they say.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What find you in it madam?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Shut it now, and I will tell ye .

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What now Lady?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: You have the worst hand that ever I saw knight have, when it is open, one can find nothing in it, and when it is shut one can get nothing out of it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The age of letting go is past madam, we must not now let go, but strike up men's heels, and take them as they fall.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: A good Cornish principle believe it Sir Cuttberd.

sp.speaker: Tales
sp.l: But I pray tell me Lady Penelope, how entertain you the love of my Cousin Sir Gyles Goose-cap.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: Are the Goose-caps a kin to you my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: Even in the first degree madam. And Sir Gyles I can tell ye, though he seem something simple, is composed of as many good parts as any knight in England.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: He should be put up for concealment then, for he shows none of them.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Are you able to reckon his good parts my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: I will do the best I can Lady, first, he dances as comely and lightly as any man, for upon my honour, I have seen him dance upon Eggs, and he has not broken them.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Nor cracked them neither.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: That I know not, indeed I would be loath, to lie though he be my kinsman, to speak more than I know by him.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Well forth my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: He has an excellent skill in all manner of perfumes, and if you bring him gloves from four pence, to forty Shillings a pair he will tell you the price of them to two pence.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: A pretty sweet quality believe me.

sp.speaker: Tales
sp.l: Nay Lady he will perfume you gloves himself; most delicately, and give them the right Spanish Titillation.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: Titillation what is that my Lord?

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.l: Why Lady it is a pretty kind of term new come up in perfuming, which they call a Titillation.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Very well expounded my Lord; forth with your kinsman's parts I pray.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.l: He is the best Sempster of any woman in England, and will work you needle work edgings, and French purls from an Angel to four Angels a year.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: That is precious ware indeed.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.l: He will work you any flower to the life, as like it as if it grew in the very place, and being a delicate perfumer, he will give it you his perfect and natural savour.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: This is wonderful; forth sweet Lord Tales.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.l: He will make you flies and worms, of all sorts most lively, and is now working a whole bed embroidered, with nothing but glow worms; whose lights he has so perfectly done, that you may go to bed in the chamber, do anything in the Chamber, without a Candle.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: Never trust me if it be not incredible; forth my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.l: He is a most excellent Turner, and will turn you wassail bowls, and posset Cups carved with Libberdes faces, and Lions heads with spouts in their mouths, to let out the posset Ale, most artificially.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Forth good Lord Tales.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: Nay good my Lord no more, you have spoken for him thoroughly I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I lay my life Cupid has short my sister in love with him out of your lips my Lord.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Well, come in my Lords, and take a bad dinner with me now, and we will all go with you at night to a better supper with the Lord, and Lady Furnifall.

sp.speaker: King. Tale.
sp.l: We attend you honourable Ladies.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: Bullaker.

sp.speaker: Bullaker.
sp.l: Aye Sir.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: Ride and catch the Captains horse.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.l: So I do Sir.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: I wonder Sir Gyles you would let him go so, and not ride after him.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.l: Would I might never be mortal Sir Cutt: if I rid not after him, till my horse sweat, so that he had never a dry thread on him, and hollod and hollod to him to stay him, till I had thought my fingers ends would have gone off with hollowings; I will be sworn to ye and; yet he ran his way like a Diogenes, and would never stay for us.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: How shall we do to get the lame Captain to London, now his horse is gone?

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.l: Why he is but a lame Jade neither Sir Moyle, we shall soon overtake him I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: And yet thou sayst thou gallopest after him as fast as thou couldst , and couldst not Catch him; I lay my life some Crab-fish has bitten thee by the tongue, thou speakest so backward still.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.l: But here is all the doubt Sir Cutt: if nobody should catch him now, when he comes at London, some boy or other would get up on him and ride him hot into the water to wash him; I will be sworn I followed one that rid my horse into the Thames, till I was up to the knees hitherto; and if it had not been for fear of going over shoes, because I am troubled with the rheum, I would have taught him to wash my horse when he was
hot i'faith; how now sweet Captain dost feel any ease in thy pain yet?

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: Ease in his pain quoth you, has good luck if he feel ease in pain I think, but would any ass in the world ride down such a hill as Highgate is, in such a frost as this, and never light

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: God is precious Sir Cutt. your Frenchman never lights I tell ye.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.l: Light Sir Cutt, Slight if I had my horse again, there is never a paltry English frost an them all should make me light.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: Go too you French Zanies you, you will follow the french steps so long, till you be not able to set one Sound step on the ground all the days of your life.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.l: Why Sir Cut: I care not if I be not sound so I be well but we were justly plagued, by this hill for following women thus.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: Aye and English women too sir Giles.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: Thou are still prating against English women I have seen none of the French dames I confess, but your greatest gallants for men in Fraunce, were here lately I am sure, and methinks there should be no more difference betwixt our Ladies and theirs, than there is betwixt our Lords and theirs, and our Lords are as far beyond them i'faith, for person, and Courtship, as they are beyond ours for phantasticallitie.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: O Lord sir Cut, I am sure our Ladies hold our Lords tack for Courtship, and yet the french Lords put them down, you noted it sir Gyles.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.l: O God sir, I stud and heard it, as I in the presence.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: How did they put them down I pray thee?

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: Why for wit, and for Courtship Sir Moile.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: As how good left handed Francois.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.l: Why Sir when Monsieur Lambois came to your mistress the Lady Hippolita as she sate in the presence, sit down here good Sir Gyles Goose-cap, he kneeled me by her thus Sir, and with a most quaint French start in his speech of ah bellissime, I desire to die now says he for your love that I might be buried here.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: A good pick thatch complement by my faith; but I prithee what answered she.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: She, I scorn to note that I hope then did he vie it again with another hah.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: That was hah, hah, I would have put the third hah to it, if I had been as my mistress, and hah, hah, haht him out of the presence i'faith,

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: Hah says he, these fair eyes, I would not for a million they were in Fraunce, they would renew all our civil wars again.

sp.speaker: Goose.
sp.l: That was not so good methinks captain.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: Well judged i'faith, there was a little wit in that I must confess, but she put him down far, and answered him with a question and that was whether he would seem a lover or a jester, if a lover a must tell her far more likelier than those, or else she was far from believing them, if a Jester, she could have much more ridiculous jests than his of twenty fools that followed the court, and told him she had as lieve be courted with a brush faggot as with a Frenchman, that spent itself all in sparks, and would sooner fire ones chimney than warm the house, and that such sparks were good enough yet to set thatched dispositions afire , but hers was tiled with sleight, and respected them as flatly.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.l: Why so Captain, and yet you talk of your great frenchmen, to God little England had never known them I may say.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: What is the matter sir Giles, are you out of love with frenchmen now of a sudden.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.l: 'slid captain Would not make one, I will be sworn, I will be sworn, they took away a mastiff dog of mine by commission now, I think on it makes my tears stand in my eyes with grief, I had rather lost the dearest friend that ever I lay withal, in my life be this light, never stir if he fought not with great Sekerson four hours to one, foremost take up hindmost, and took so many loaves from him, that he starved him presently: So at last the dog could do no more than a Bear could do, and the bear being heavy with hunger you know, fell upon the dog, broke his back, and the dog never stirred more.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: Why thou sayst the frenchmen took him away.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.l: Frenchmen, Aye , so they did too, but yet and he had not been killed, it would never a grieved me.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: O excellent unity of speech.

body.stage: Enter Will and Iacke at seuerall doores.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.l: Save ye knights.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Save you Captain.

sp.speaker: Faul.
sp.l: Pages, welcome my fine pages.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: Welcome boys.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.l: Welcome sweet Will, good Iacke.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: But how chance you are so far from London now pages, is it not almost dinner time.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.l: Yes indeed Sir, but we left our fellows to wait for once, and could not choose in pure love to your worships, but we must needs come and meet you, before you met our Ladies, to tell you a secret.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.l: A secret, what secret I pray thee?

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: If ever your worships say anything , we are undone forever.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.l: Not for a world believe it.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.l: Why then this it is; we overheard our Ladies as they were talking in private say they refused to meet you at Barnet this morning of purpose, because they would try which of you were most patient.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: And some said you, Sir Gyles, another you Sir and the third you Captain,

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: This was excellent.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.l: Then did they swear one another not to excuse themselves to you by any means, that they might try you the better, now if they shall see you say nothing in the world to them, what may come of it, when Ladies begin to try their suitors once, I hope your wisdoms can judge a little.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: O ho my little knave let us alone now i'faith, would I might be Cashiered, if I say anything .

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: Faith and I can forbear my Tongue as well as another I hope.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.l: Would I might be degraded if I speak a word, I will tell them I care not for loosing my labour.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: Come knights shall we not reward the pages?

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: Yes I prithee do, Sir Gyles give the boys something.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.l: Never stir Sir Cutt, if I have ever a groat about me but one three pence.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: Well knights I will lay out for us all, here my fine pages.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.l: No indeed if it please your worship.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: O pages refuse a gentleman's bounty.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Cry you mercy Sir, thank you sweet Captain

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: And what other news is stirring my fine villiacos.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.l: Marry Sir they are invited to a great supper tonight to your Lords house Captain, the Lord Furnifall, and there will be your great cousin Sir Gyles Goose-cap, the Lord Tales and your uncle Sir Cutt. Rudesby, Sir Cutbert Kingcob.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: The Lord Tales, what countryman is he?

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: A kentish Lord Sir, his ancestors came forth off Canterbury.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: Out of Canterbury.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.l: Aye indeed Sir the best Tales in England are your Canterbury tales, I assure ye.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: the boy tells thee true Captain.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: He writes his name Sir, Tales, and he being the tenth son his father had; his father Christened him Decem Tales, and so his whole name is the Lord Decem Tales.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.l: Ah my mortality the boy knows more than I do of our house.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: But is the Lady Furnifall (Captain) still of the same drinking humour she was wont to be.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: Still of the same knight, and is never in any sociable vain till she be tipsy, for in her sobriety she is mad, and fears my good little old Lord out of all proportion.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And therefore as I hear he will earnestly invite guests to his house, of purpose to make his wife drunk, and then dotes on her humour most profanely.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: It is very true knight; we will sup with them tonight; and you shall see her; and I now think of it, I will tell you a thing knights, wherein perhaps you may exceedingly pleasure me.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.l: What is that good Captain.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: I am desirous to help my Lord to a good merry Fool, and if I could help him to a good merry one, he might do me very much credit I assure ye.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: 'Sblood thou speakest to us as if we could serve thy turn.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: O Fraunce Sir Cutt: your Frenchman would not have taken me so, for a world, but because Fools come into your companies many times to make you merry

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: As thou dost.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.l: Nay good Sir Cutt: you know fools do come into your companies.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: Aye and thou knowest it too, no man better.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: Bear with Choler Sir Gyles.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: But would you help your Lord to a good fool so fain Sir.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: Aye my good page exceeding fain.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: You mean a wench, do you not Sir, a foolish wench?

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: Nay I would have a man fool, for his Lord: page.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.l: Does his Lord: love a fool, so well I pray.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: Assure thyself page, my Lord loves a fool as he loves himself.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Of what degree would you have your Fool Sir, for you may have of all manner of degrees.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: Faith I would have him a good Emphatical fool, one that would make my Lord laugh well, and I card not,

sp.speaker: Will
sp.l: Laugh well (um) then we must know this Sir, is your Lord Costive of laughter, or laxative of laughter?

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: Nay he is good merry little Lord, and indeed something Laxative of Laughter.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Why then Sir the less wit will serve his Lordships turn, marry if he had been Costive of laughter, he must have had two or three drams of wit the more in his fool, for we must minister according to the quantity of his Lord: humour you know, and if he should have as much Wit in his fool being Laxative of laughter, as if he were Costive of Laughter, why he might laugh himself into an Epilepsy, and fall down dead suddenly, as many have done with the extremity of that passion; and I know your Lord cares for nothing, but the health of a fool.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: Thou art in the right my notable good page.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Why, and for that health Sir we will warrant his Lordship, that if he should have all Bacon de sanitate tuenda read to him, it should not please his Lordship so well as our fool shall.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: Gramercy my more than English pages.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.l: On my word I have not seen pages have so much wit, that have never been in Fraunce Captain.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: It is true indeed Sir Gyles, well then my almost french Elixirs, will you help my Lord to a fool, so fit for him as you say.

sp.speaker: Will;
sp.l: As fit, I will warrant you Captain, as if he were made for him, and he shall come this night to supper, and fool where his Lord: sits at table.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: Excellent fit, fail not now my sweet pages.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Not for a world sir, we will go both, and seek him presently.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: Do so my good wags

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Save you knights.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Save you Captain.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: Farewell my pretty knaves, come knights, shall we resolve to go to this Supper?

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: What else.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.l: And let us provide torches for our men to sit at door withal captain.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: That we will I warrant you sir Giles.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: Torches? why the Moon will shine man.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.l: The moon Sir Cut I scorn the moon i'faith, 'slid sometimes a man shall not get her to shine and if he would give her a couple of Capons, and one of them must be white too, God forgive me I could never abide her since yesterday, she served me such a trick the other night.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: What trick sir Gyles?

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.l: Why sir Cut: because the days be mortal and short now you know, and I love day light well; I thought it went a way faster than it needed, and run after it into Finsburie fields in the calm evening to see the windmills go; and even as I was going over a ditch the moon by this light of purpose runs me behind a cloud, and lets me fall into the ditch by heaven.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: That was ill done in her in deed sir Giles.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.l: Ill done sir Cut: 'slid a man may bear, and bear, but and she have no more good manners, but to make every black slovenly cloud a pearl in her eye I shall never love English moon again, while I live I will be sworn to ye.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.l: come knights to London horse, horse, horse.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: In what a case he is with the poor English moon, because the french moons (their torches) will be the less in fashion, and I warrant you the Captain will remember it too, though he say nothing , he seconds his resolute chase so and follows him, I will lay my life you shall see them the next cold night, shut the moonshine out of their chambers, and make it lie without doors all night. I discredit my wit with their companies now I think on it, plague a god on them; I will fall abeating on them presently.

body.stage: Enter Lorde Momford and Clarence. Clarence Horatio.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Sing good Horatio, while I sigh and write.
According to my master Platos mind
The Soul is music, and doth therefore joy
In accents musical, which he that hates
With points of discord is together tied
And barks at Reason, Consonant in sense.
Divine Eugenia, bears the ocular form
Of music and of Reason, and presents
The Soul exempt from flesh in flesh inflamed,
Who must not love her then, that loves his soul?
To her I write, my friend, the star of friends
Will needs have my strange lines greet her strange eyes
And for his sake I will pour my poor Soul forth
In floods of Ink; but did not his kind hand
Bar me with violent grace, I would consume.
In the white flames of her impassionate Love
Ere my harsh lips should vent the odorous blaze.
For I am desperate of all worldly Joys
And there was never man so harsh to men,
When I am fullest of digested life
I seem a liveless Embrion to all
Each day racked up in night-like Funeral.
Sing good Horatio, whilst I sigh and write.
Suffer him to love that suffers not loving, my love is without passion and therefore free from alteration.
Prose is too harsh, and verse is poetry
Why should I write then? merit clad in Ink
Is but a mourner, and as good as naked
I will not write my friend shall speak for me
Sing one stave more my good Horatio.
I must remember I know whom I love ,
A dame of learning, and of life exempt
From all the Idle fancies of her sex,
And this that to another dame would seem
Perplexed and folded in a ruthless vail
Will be more clear than ballads to her eye
I will write, if but to satisfy my friend.
Your third stance sweet Horatio and no more.
How vainly do I offer my strange love ?
Aye marry, and bid states, and entertain
Ladies with tales and jests, and Lords with news
And keep a house to feast Acteons hounds
That eat their master, and let idle guests
Draw me from serious search of things divine
To bid them sit, and welcome, and take care
To sooth their palates with choice kitchen stuff
As all must do that marry and keep house
And then look on the left sid of my yoke
Or on the right perhaps and see my wife
Draw in a quite repugnant course from me
Busied to starch her french purls, and her puffs
When I am in my Anima reflexa quid sit flicitas qu origo rerum?
And make these beings that are known to be
The only serious objects of true men
Seem shadows, with substantial stir she keeps
About her shadows, which if husbands love
They must believe, and thus my other self
Brings me another body to dispose
That have already much too much of one,
And must not look for any Soul of her
To help two rule to bodies.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Fie for shame.
I never heard of such an antedame.
Do women bring no help of soul to men?
Why friend they either are men's souls themselves
Or the most witty Imitatrixes of them
Or prettiest sweet apes of human Souls,
That ever Nature framed; as I will prove.
For first they be Substanti lucidae
And purer than men's bodies like their souls,
Which men's harsh hairs both of their breast and chin
Occasioned by their gross and ruder heat
Plainly demonstrates: Then like souls they do,
Mouere corpora, for no power on earth
Moves a man's body, as a woman does!
Then do they Dare formas corpori
Or add fair forms to men, as their souls do:
For but for women, who would care for forms?
I vow I never would wash face, nor hands
Nor care how ragged, or slovenly I went
Were it not for women, who of all men's pomps
Are the true final causes: Then they make
Men in their Seeds immortal like their Souls
That else would perish in a span of time.
O they be soul-like creatures, and my Niece
The Soul of twenty rare Souls styled in one.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: That, that it is my Lord, that makes me love.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: O are ye come Sir, welcome to my Niece
As I may say at midnight gentle friend
What have you wrote I pray?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Strange stuff my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Indeed the way to believe is to love
And the right way to love is to believe,
This I will carry now with pen and Ink
For her to use in answer, see, sweet friend
She shall not stay to call, but while the steel
Of her affection is made soft and hot,
I will strike and take occasion by the brow.
Blessed is the wooing that is not long adoing .

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Had ever man so true, and noble friend?
Or would men think this sharpe worlds freezing Air
To all true honour and judicial love
Would suffer such a flourishing pine in both
To overlook the box-trees of this time?
When the learned mind hath by impulsion wrought
Her eyes clear fire into a knowing flame.
No elemental smoke can darken it
Nor Northern coldness nip her Daphnean flower,
O sacred friendship thanks to thy kind power
That being retired from all the faithless world
Appearest to me in my unworldly friend,
And for thine own sake let his noble mind
By moving precedent to all his kind
(Like just Deucalion) of earths stony bones
Repair the world with human blood and flesh
And dying virtue with new life refresh.

body.stage: Enter Tales, Kingcob, Eugenia, Hippolita, Penelope, Winnifred.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It is time to leave your Chests Ladies it is too studious an exercise after dinner.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.l: Why is it called Chests?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Because they lean upon their Chests that play at it.

sp.speaker: Tal
sp.l: I would have it called the strife of wits, for it is a game so witty, that with strife for mastery, we hunt it eagerly.

sp.speaker: Eug
sp.l: Specially where the wit of the Goose-caps are in chase my Lord.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.l: I am a Goose-cap by the mothers side madam, at least my mother was a Goose-cap.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: And you were her white son, I warrant my Lord.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.l: I was the youngest Lady, and therefore must be her white son ye know, the youngest of ten I was.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: And the wisest of Fifteen.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.l: And sweet Lady will ye cast a kind eye now upon my Cousin, Sir Gyles Goose-cap.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Pardon my Lord I have never a spare eye to cast away I assure ye.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.l: I wonder you should Count it cast away Lady upon him, do you remember those few of his good parts I rehearsed to you.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Very perfectly my Lord, amongst which one of them was, that he is the best Sempster of any woman in England, pray let us see some of his work?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Sweet Lord let us see him sow a little.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.l: You shall on mine honour Lady.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: He is a goodly great knight indeed; and a little needle in his hand will become him prettily.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: From the Spanish pike to the Spanish needle, he shall play with any knight in England Lady.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: But not e conuerso, from the Spanish needle to the Spanish pike.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I think he be too wise for that indeed madam, for he has twenty miles length in land lies together, and he would be loath to bring it all to the length of a pike.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: But no man commends my blunt Servant Sir Cutt: Rudesby methinks.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: He is a kind gentleman Lady though he be blunt, and is of this humour, the more you presume upon him without Ceremony, the more he loves you, if he know you think him kind once and will say nothing but still use him, you may melt him into any kindness you will, he is right like a woman, and had rather, you should bluntly take the greatest favour you can of him, than shamefastly entreat it.

sp.speaker: Eug
sp.l: He says well to you Hippolita.

sp.speaker: Hip
sp.l: Aye madam, but they say, he will beat one in Jest, and byte in kindness, and tear ones ruffs in Courtship.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Some that he makes sport withal perhaps, but none that he respects I assure ye.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: And what is his living sir Cutbeard?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Some two thousand a year Lady.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I pray do not tell him that I asked, for I stand not upon living.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: O Good Lady who can live without living ?

sp.speaker: Mom
sp.l: Still here Lordings? good companions i'faith, I see you come not for victuals.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.l: Victuals, my Lord, I hope we have victuals at home.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Aye but sweet Lord, there is a principle in the Politicians physic, Eat not your meat upon other men's trenchers, and beware of surfeits of your own cost many good companions cannot abide to eat meat at home ye know. And how fairs my noble Niece now, and her fair Lady Fears?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: What wind blows you hither trow?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Hark you madam, the sweet gale of one Clarences breath, with this his paper sail blows me hither.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Aye me still, in that humour? beshrew my heart if I take any Papers from him.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Kind bosom do thou take it then.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Nay then never trust me.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Let it fall then, or cast it away you were best, that everybody may discover your love suits, do; there is somebody near if you note it, and how have you spent the time since dinner nobles?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: At chests my Lords,

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Read it niece.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Here bear it back I pray.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: I bear you on my back to hear you; and how play the Ladies sir Cuthbert, what men do they play best withal, with knights or rooks?

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.l: With knights my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: It is pity their board is no broader, and that some men called gulls are not added to their game

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why my Lo it needs not, they make the knights gulls.

sp.speaker: Mom
sp.l: That is pretty sir Cuthbert; you have begone I know Niece, forth I command you.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: O ye are a sweet uncle.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: I have brought her a little Greek, to help me out withal, and she is so coy of her learning for sooth she makes it strange: Lords, and Ladies, I invite you all to supper tonight, and you shall not deny me.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We will attend your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.l: Come Ladies let us into the gallery a little.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: And now what says mine own dear niece i'faith?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: What should she say to the backside of a paper.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Come, come, I know you have been at the belly side.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Now was there ever Lord so prodigal, of his own honoured blood, and dignity?

sp.speaker: Mom
sp.l: Away with these same horse fair allegations, will you answer the letter?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: God is my life you go like a cunning spokes man, man, answer uncle? what do ye think me desperate of a husband

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Not so niece, but careless of your poor uncle.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I will not write that is certain.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: What will you have my friend and I perish, do you thirst our bloods?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: O ye are in a mighty danger no doubt on it.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: If you have our bloods beware our ghosts I can tell ye, come will ye write?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I will not write i'faith.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: i'faith dame, then I must be your secretary I see, here is the letter, come, do you dictate and I will write.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: If you write no otherwise than I dictate, it will scarce prove a kind answer I believe.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: But you will be advised I trust. Secretaries are of counsel with their countesses, thus it begins. Suffer him to love, that suffers not loving, what answer you to that?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: He loves extremely that suffers not in love.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: He answers you for that presently, his love is without passion, and therefore free from alteration, for Pati you know is in Alterationem labi; he loves you in his soul he tells you, wherein there is no passion, say dame what answer you.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Nay if I answer anything.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Why? very well, I will answer for you.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: You answer? shall I set my hand to your answer?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Aye by my faith shall ye.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: By my faith, but you shall answer as I would have you then.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Always put in with advice of your secretary, niece, come, what answer you?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Since you needs will have my Answer, I will Answer briefly to the first, and last part of his letter.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Do so Niece, and leave the midst for himself in gods name, what is your answer?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I cannot but suffer you to love, if you do love .

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.l: Why very good, there it is, and will requite your love; say you so?

sp.speaker: Eug.
